story:
Become part of the growing community of people dedicated to spreading the universal language of music, and the healing power of music. Through our non-profit campaign help us distribute and deliver free music and MP3 players to thousands of individuals who would not otherwise have access to this music.  


Who We Are

Music Has Healing Power is a newly formed verified California, USA non-profit foundation and the brainchild of Cinema Show Music, www.cinemashowmusic.com an existing 38-year old award winning and multi Grammy winning music and sound production company. Our mission is to bring healing, empowerment and awareness through music listening, to millions of individuals throughout the global community facilitated by the healing power of music.  Music Has Healing Power intends to make music accessible to individuals who otherwise would not have access to this music. www.MusicHasHealingPower.org


The Campaign

Not all people in the global community have ready access to music and its availability. Millions of people who are afflicted with physical or mental illness may not have access to music, and to the benefits that listening to one’s favorite music can bring.  In its simplest form music can bring the healing power to anyone that listens.

We all know that music is in our lives every day and in every way. Music is not only on the radio, but on television, in motion pictures, as soundtrack in the electronic games we play, broadcast and download music available in many forms.

Music has been around since the very beginnings of time, from ancient tribal drums and sounds through development of technology over decades to modern times. 

Music and it’s rhythmic motions can be as simple as anyone tapping their foot to a song or sound or humming a tune in our heads that brings back memories. Music is and has been alive and well. Music drives our lives and has great effect on all of us in one-way or another. It has been scientifically established  that music does indeed have healing power. Music may well be considered the universal language. 


The Campaign Plan

The mission of Music Has Healing Power foundation is to bring healing, empowerment and awareness throughout the global community by delivering free music through distribution of individual MP3 players to needing recipients. These recipients can be an individual family member, a known friend or a group of people in a gathered situation such as a hospital, hospice or other community facilities. We will reach people who are in need and who have been inflicted with illness or disease, disability, as well as, people who have the inability to afford music & an MP3 player to use for the healing power of music.


How the Campaign Plan will work

Through our Indiegogo campaign and the efforts of individual backer’s donations, we will reach out to the global community asking for individual stories of people or of an individual person in need of our free music and MP3 player(s). 

Your story is important!  Please click here and provide your story and Music Has Healing Power will respond back to your submitted request: 



You will be asked to tell us why the person(s) you are requesting music and MP3 player(s) for would benefit from receiving our foundation’s music and MP3 player(s) and how this music would impact this person or people.

  • Any links, websites, articles you can provide us with will be helpful.
  • Your Story should contain as much information about the person or people as is needed to explain their situation.
  • Specific genre of music can be requested based on each person’s preference in music. Genres or styles of music include:
    • Pop, Rock, Dance, R&B, Hip-Hop, Country, Classical, Jazz, Gospel, World/New Age, Latin, Asian, Reggae, African, Middle Eastern, Big Band and more.
  • Each person’s favorite genre of music is best for their own listening pleasure. We will use our best resources to provide the specific requested genres of music. Requested music will come from Music Has Healing Power’s associated company, Cinema Show Music, a multi award winning, multi Grammy winning music and sound production studio in southern California, USA. The music we will deliver will be original license free music composed, produced & recorded by top international music professionals.

The success of this campaign & our non-profit foundation music recipients depends on all of your donations, including the perks.  Thank you for being a part of this global endeavor. 


What will the money be used for as donated through Indiegogo

1.  Purchase of new MP3 players for music giveaway.

2.  Full music Compositions/Production expenses for free music giveaway.

3.  Administrative costs (shipping, postage, packaging, etc) involved with music & MP3 player(s) shipments.

4.  New primary staff salaries. Based on success of campaign and total response for music requests. (Volunteers will make up much of the staff)


Our Projected Overview Budget

1.  Purchase of new MP3 players equipment for music giveaway = $225,000. 37.5% of campaign goal.

2.  Full music Compositions/Production expenses for free music giveaway = $191,000. 31.8% of campaign goal.

3.  Administration costs: (shipping, packaging, postage, etc) = $61,000. 10.2% of campaign goal.

4.  New primary staff salaries = $123,000. Based on success of campaign and total response for music requests. 20.5% of campaign goal.

                                                                FAQ

  Music Has Healing Power is a verified California, USA non-profit corporation

  IRS  EIN number 81-1539684

                                               

Cinema Show Music Can Be Heard On:  (Many more available) 


The Story

The healing power of music has been referenced for centuries. Throughout history the idea of music as a healing modality was well founded in Chinese, Egyptian and Greek history, suggesting music is comforting, soothing and restorative for the soul.


Contemporary research shows that music therapy benefits patients with stress, psychological and physical problems. This brings about a sense of well being which helps manage illnesses of all kinds.  Renowned Dr. Oliver Sachs, neurologist, claims “music is the pathway in all patients”.  

http://www.oliversacks.com/books-by-oliver-sacks/musicophilia/  

A recent study in the Journal of Advanced Nursing, published in the UK, concluded that people with depression who listened to music at least one hour each day reported a reduction of symptoms of up to 25%. Another study by researchers at the Cleveland Clinic in the US found that music helps ease unrelenting, non-malignant pain in patients. Music has also been found effective in managing pain caused by cancerous conditions in the body and procedural pain such as chemotherapy.

Dr. Diana Vetter, a lead surgery researcher at the University of Zurich in Switzerland, said “Informing our patients before scheduled surgeries of the positive effect of music on their wellbeing could be a low cost intervention that may enhance wellbeing and possibly faster recovery”.

To assess the impact of music on surgical outcomes, Vetter and colleagues analyzed data from 47 studies, including 26 that looked at the effect of music before procedures, 25 looking at music in the operating room, and 25 looking at music during recovery. Overall, music was linked to about 31 percent less pain, 29 percent lower odds of using pain medication, and 34 percent less anxiety. In addition, music was tied to 40 percent lower blood pressure and 27 percent lower heart rate.

"There now seems to be enough evidence to support the formal adaptation of music interventions in clinical guidelines." said Marianne van der Heijden, a researcher at Erasmus Medical Center - Sophia Children's Hospital in Rotterdam, The Netherlands.

Music interventions shouldn't be difficult to provide at all and could be realized by creating awareness among hospital staff, patients and their family members about the positive effects of music," van der Heijden added. http://news.yahoo.com/music-not-just-good-soul-good-body-180422525.html

Watch Video Link Henry’s Story - Visualize the healing power of music – Truly Amazing

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5FWn4JB2YLU

The Story Continued

Music Therapy is an established health profession in which music is used to address physical, emotional, cognitive, and social needs of individuals. Music therapy also provides avenues for communication that can be helpful to those who find it difficult to express themselves in words. Research in music therapy supports its effectiveness in many areas such as: overall physical rehabilitation and facilitating movement, increasing people's motivation to become engaged in their treatment, providing emotional support for clients and their families, and providing an outlet for expression of feelings. 

Examples of therapeutic music which are noteworthy, from American Music Therapy Association, (AMTA)

- A person with Alzheimer’s listening to an MP3 player with headphones of his/her favorite songs.

- A piano player in the lobby of a hospital

- Nurses playing background music for patients

- Arts educators

- A high school student playing guitar in a nursing home

- A choir singing on the pediatric floor of a hospital


Top 12 brain-based reasons why music works in therapy, by Karen Merzenich, writer-editor Brain HQ from Science Post, May 10, 2013

1.  Music is a core function in our brain. Our brain is primed early on to respond to and process music. Research has shown that day-old infants are able to detect differences in rhythmic patterns.Mothers across cultures and throughout time have used lullabies and rhythmic rocking to calm crying babies. From an evolutionary standpoint, music precedes language. We don’t yet know why, but our brains are wired to respond to music.

2.  Our bodies entrain to rhythm. Have you ever walked down the street, humming a song in your head, and noticed that your walking to the beat? That’s called entrainment. Our motor systems naturally entrain, or match, to a rhythmic beat. When a musical input enters our central nervous system via the auditory nerve, most of the input goes to the brain for processing. But some of it heads straight to motor nerves in our spinal cord. This allows our muscles to move to the rhythm without our having to think about it or “try.” It’s how we dance to music, tap our foot to a rhythm, and walk in time to a beat. This is also why music therapists can help a person who’s had a stroke re-learn how to walk and develop strength and endurance in their upper bodies.

3.  We have physiologic responses to music. Every time your breathing quickens, your heart-rate increases, or you feel a shiver down your spine, that’s your body responding physiologically to music. Qualified music therapists can use this to help stimulate a person in a coma or use music to effectively help someone relax.

4.  Children (even infants) respond readily to music. Any parent knows that it’s natural for a child to begin dancing and singing at an early age. My kids both started rocking to music before they turned one. And have you seen the YouTube video of the baby dancing to Beyonce? Children learn through music, art, and play, so it’s important (even necessary) to use those mediums when working with children in therapy.

5.  Music taps into our emotions. Have you ever listened to a piece of music and smiled? Or felt sad? Whether from the music itself, or from our associations with the music, music taps into our emotional systems. Many people use this in a “therapeutic” way, listening to certain music that makes them feel a certain way. The ability for music to easily access our emotions is very beneficial for music therapists.

6.  Music helps improve our attention skills. I was once working with a 4-year-old in the hospital. Her 10-month-old twin sisters were visiting, playing with Grandma on the bed. As soon as I started singing to the older sister, the twins stopped playing and stared at me, for a full 3 minutes. Even from an early age, music can grab and hold our attention. This allows music therapists to target attention and impulse control goals, both basic skills we need to function and succeed.

7.  Music uses shared neural circuits as speech. This is almost a no-brainer (no pun intended), but listening to or singing music with lyrics uses shared neural circuits as listening to and expressing speech. Music therapists can use this ability to help a child learn to communicate or help someone who’s had a stroke re-learn how to talk again.

8.  Music enhances learning. Do you remember how you learned your ABCs? Through a song! The inherent structure and emotional pull of music makes it an easy tool for teaching concepts, ideas, and information. Music is an effective mnemonic device and can “tag” information, not only making it easy to learn, but also easy to later recall.

9.  Music taps into our memories. Have you ever been driving, heard a song on the radio, then immediately been taken to a certain place, a specific time in your life, or a particular person? Music is second only to smell for its ability to stimulate our memory in a very powerful way. Music therapists who work with older adults with dementia have countless stories of how music stimulates their clients to reminisce about their life.

10.  Music is a social experience. Our ancestors bonded and passed on their stories and knowledge through song, stories, and dance. Even today, many of our music experiences are shared with a group, whether playing in band or an elementary music class, listening to jazz at a restaurant, or singing in church choir. Music makes it easy for music therapists to structure and facilitate a group process.

11.  Music is predictable, structured, and organized–and our brain likes it! Music often has a predictable steady beat, organized phrases, and a structured form. If you think of most country/folk/pop/rock songs you know, they’re often organized with a verse-chorus structure. They’re organized in a way that we like and enjoy listening to over and over again. Even sound waves that make up a single tone or an entire chord are organized in mathematical ratios–and our brains really like this predictability and structure.

12.  Music is non-invasive, safe and motivating. We can’t forget that most people really enjoy music. This is not the most important reason why music works in therapy, but it’s the icing on the cake.

The Evidence On Music Therapy Continued, from Evidence – Based Living, Cornell University

We’ve all heard the idiom, “Music is good for the soul.” But, according to the evidence, it’s good for your health as well.

A new study published in the Journal of the American Medical Association found that children admitted to the emergency department who listened to music during routine procedures showed less distress and reported lower pain scores than those who didn’t listen to music.

The study included a total of 42 children aged 3 to 11 years who had an IV line placed. Half of them were randomly selected to listen to music selected by a music therapist during the procedure. Health care providers reported that it was easier to insert the IV line in children who were listening to the music and health providers also reported more satisfaction with the placement compared to those who did not listen to music.

Those are some convincing results, but still only a single study. So we went looking for systematic reviews on the impact of music in medical settings. It turns out, there is plenty more evidence showing the positive effects of music on health.  Among them:

  • A 2011 review published in the Cochrane libraries found music therapy and music medicine interventions can help cancer patients. The review found some positive effects of music on anxiety, pain, mood, quality of life, heart rate, respiratory rate, and blood pressure.
  • Another Cochrane review published in 2009 looked for studies measuring whether music therapy is useful in treating depression. The reviewers only found five studies appropriate for the review. Four of them concluded that patients exposed to music therapy had a greater reduction in symptoms compared to those who didn’t listen to music.
  • And a third review published in the Journal of Advanced Nursing in 2002 looked at the impact of music therapy on patients admitted to the hospital. Researchers reviewed 19 studies, and found music therapy improved patients anxiety levels in the hospital. Researchers recommended music therapy as an effective way to calm patients.

The bottom line: There is plenty of evidence to show that music therapy used in health care settings  can help calm patients. And given there are no side effects associated to music listening, it’s certainly a treatment worth trying.


Benefits Of Music In Schools

Nearly everyone enjoys music, whether by listening to it, singing, or playing an instrument. But despite this almost universal interest, many schools are having to do away with their music education programs. This is a mistake, with schools losing not only an enjoyable subject, but a subject that can enrich students’ lives and education. Read on to learn why music education is so important, and how it offers benefits even beyond itself.

1. Musical training helps develop language and reasoning: Students who have early musical training will develop the areas of the brain related to language and reasoning. The left side of the brain is better developed with music, and songs can help imprint information on young minds.

2. A mastery of memorization: Even when performing with sheet music, student musicians are constantly using their memory to perform. The skill of memorization can serve students well in education and beyond.

3. Students learn to improve their work: Learning music promotes craftsmanship, and students learn to want to create good work instead of mediocre work. This desire can be applied to all subjects of study.

4. Increased coordination: Students who practice with musical instruments can improve their hand-eye coordination. Just like playing sports, children can develop motor skills when playing music.

5. A sense of achievement: Learning to play pieces of music on a new instrument can be a challenging, but achievable goal. Students who master even the smallest goal in music will be able to feel proud of their achievement.

6. Kids stay engaged in school: An enjoyable subject like music can keep kids interested and engaged in school. Student musicians are likely to stay in school to achieve in other subjects.

7. Success in society: Music is the fabric of our society, and music can shape abilities and character. Students in band or orchestra are less likely to abuse substances over their lifetime. Musical education can greatly contribute to children’s intellectual development as well.

8. Emotional development: Students of music can be more emotionally developed, with empathy towards other cultures They also tend to have higher self esteem and are better at coping with anxiety.

9. Students learn pattern recognition: Children can develop their math and pattern-recognition skills with the help of musical education. Playing music offers repetition in a fun format.

10. Better SAT scores: Students who have experience with music performance or appreciation score higher on the SAT. One report indicates 63 points higher on verbal and 44 points higher on math for students in music appreciation courses.

11. Fine-tuned auditory skills: Musicians can better detect meaningful, information-bearing elements in sounds, like the emotional meaning in a baby’s cry. Students who practice music can have better auditory attention, and pick out predictable patterns from surrounding noise.

12. Music builds imagination and intellectual curiosity: Introducing music in the early childhood years can help foster a positive attitude toward learning and curiosity. Artistic education develops the whole brain and develops a child’s imagination.

13. Music can be relaxing: Students can fight stress by learning to play music. Soothing music is especially helpful in helping kids relax.

14. Musical instruments can teach discipline: Kids who learn to play an instrument can learn a valuable lesson in discipline. They will have to set time aside to practice and rise to the challenge of learning with discipline to master playing their instrument.

15. Preparation for the creative economy: Investing in creative education can prepare students for the 21st century workforce. The new economy has created more artistic careers, and these jobs may grow faster than others in the future.

16. Development in creative thinking: Kids who study the arts can learn to think creatively. This kind of education can help them solve problems by thinking outside the box and realizing that there may be more than one right answer.

17. Music can develop spatial intelligence: Students who study music can improve the development of spatial intelligence, which allows them to perceive the world accurately and form mental pictures. Spatial intelligence is helpful for advanced mathematics and more.

18. Kids can learn teamwork: Many musical education programs require teamwork as part of a band or orchestra. In these groups, students will learn how to work together and build camaraderie.

19. Responsible risk-taking: Performing a musical piece can bring fear and anxiety. Doing so teaches kids how to take risks and deal with fear, which will help them become successful and reach their potential.

20. Better self-confidence: With encouragement from teachers and parents, students playing a musical instrument can build pride and confidence. Musical education is also likely to develop better communication for students.

~ ~ ~


Notable Music Quotes:

Mitchell Gaynor, M.D., Sounds of Healing

"You can look at disease as a form of disharmony. And there's no organ system in the body that's not affected by sound and music and vibration. "

 Oliver Sachs, M.D.

"I regard music therapy as a tool of great power in many neurological disorders -- Parkinson's and Alzheimer's -- because of its unique capacity to organize or reorganize cerebral function when it has been damaged."

Dr. Ira Altschuler (of the Eloise State Hospital) (1942)

"Eventually , musical therapists will compose prescriptions after the manner of a pharmacist...."

Corinne Heline (1882-1975)

"The magic of "Musical Medicine" will come into its own. The application of such healing potencies will not be limited just to man's body and mind. It will be an agency for building and healing his soul as well. "

Aristotle (322-384 BC)

"Emotions of any kind can be evoked by melody and rhythm; therefore music has the power to form character. "

Robert Assagioli M.D.(1888-1974) Founder of Transpersonal Psychology

"We trust that the magic of sound, will contribute an ever greater measure to the relief of human suffering." 

Beethoven (1770-1827)

"Music is the mediator between the life of the senses and the life of the spirit."


Shipping Information:

We plan to ship worldwide!  However, please note:  Every country has its own shipping regulations and rules.  If your country, (for some reason) says we cannot ship it there, then you will be issued a full refund.

Delivery of rewards/perks are subject to best efforts and the success of Indiegogo contributors supporting the campaign.

Meet the Team


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't specifically donate at this time, please help spread the word of our foundation with your friends and family and direct them to our campaign site here or our website: www.MusicHasHealingPower.org 

Please Help Make This Campaign successful. Thank You !

"Music really does have healing power".

With all of your help and by spreading the word, we are fully committed to making Music Has Healing Power a reality for many individuals and communities throughout the world.
story_txt:
Become part of the growing community of
people dedicated to spreading the universal language of music, and the healing
power of music. Through our non-profit campaign help us distribute and deliver free music and MP3 players to thousands of individuals who would not otherwise have access to
this music.  


Who We Are
Music Has Healing Power is a newly
formed verified California, USA non-profit foundation and the brainchild of Cinema Show Music, www.cinemashowmusic.com an existing
38-year old award winning and multi Grammy winning music and sound
production company. Our mission is to bring healing, empowerment and awareness through music listening, to millions of individuals throughout the global community facilitated by the healing power of music.  Music Has Healing Power intends to make music accessible to individuals who otherwise would not have access to this music. www.MusicHasHealingPower.org

The Campaign
Not all people in the global community have ready access to music and its availability. Millions of people who are afflicted with physical or mental illness may not have access to music, and to the benefits that listening to one’s favorite music can bring.  In its simplest form music can bring the healing power to anyone that listens.
We all know that music is in our lives every day and in every way. Music is not only on the
radio, but on television, in motion pictures, as soundtrack in the electronic
games we play, broadcast and download music available in many forms.
Music has
been around since the very beginnings of time, from ancient tribal drums and
sounds through development of technology over decades to modern times. 
Music and it’s rhythmic motions can be as simple as
anyone tapping their foot to a song or sound or humming a tune in our heads
that brings back memories. Music is and has been
alive and well. Music drives our lives and has great effect on all of us in
one-way or another. It has been scientifically established  that music does indeed have healing power. Music may well be considered the universal
language. 

The Campaign Plan
The mission of Music Has Healing Power
foundation is to bring healing, empowerment and awareness throughout the global
community by delivering free music through distribution of individual MP3 players to
needing recipients. These recipients can be an individual family member, a
known friend or a group of people in a gathered situation such as a hospital,
hospice or other community facilities. We will reach people who are in need and
who have been inflicted with illness or disease, disability, as well as, people
who have the inability to afford music & an MP3 player to use for the
healing power of music. 

How the Campaign Plan will work
Through our Indiegogo campaign and the efforts of individual backer’s donations, we will reach out to the global community asking for individual stories of people or of an individual person in need of our free music and MP3 player(s). 
Your story is important!  Please click here and provide your story and Music Has Healing Power will respond back to your submitted request: 




You will be asked to tell us why the person(s) you are requesting music and MP3 player(s) for would benefit from receiving our foundation’s music and MP3 player(s) and how this music would impact this person or people.


Any links, websites, articles you can provide us with will be helpful.
Your Story should contain as much information about the person or people as is needed to explain their situation.
Specific genre of music can be requested based on each person’s preference in music. Genres or styles of music include:

Pop, Rock, Dance, R&B, Hip-Hop, Country, Classical, Jazz, Gospel, World/New Age, Latin, Asian, Reggae, African, Middle Eastern, Big Band and more.
          


Each person’s favorite genre of music is best for their own listening pleasure. We will use our best resources to provide the specific requested genres of music. Requested music will come from Music Has Healing Power’s associated company, Cinema Show Music, a multi award winning, multi Grammy winning music and sound production studio in southern California, USA. The music we will deliver will be original license free music composed, produced & recorded by top international music professionals. 


The success of this campaign & our non-profit foundation music recipients depends on all of your donations, including the perks.  Thank you for being a part of this global endeavor. 

What will the money be used for as donated
through Indiegogo
1. 
Purchase of new MP3 players for music giveaway.
2. 
Full music Compositions/Production expenses for
free music giveaway. 
3. 
Administrative costs (shipping, postage,
packaging, etc) involved with music & MP3 player(s) shipments. 
4. 
New primary staff salaries. Based on success of
campaign and total response for music requests. (Volunteers will make up much
of the staff)

Our Projected Overview Budget
1. 
Purchase of new MP3 players equipment for music
giveaway = $225,000. 37.5% of campaign goal.
2. 
Full music Compositions/Production expenses for
free music giveaway = $191,000. 31.8% of campaign goal.
3. 
Administration costs: (shipping, packaging,
postage, etc) = $61,000. 10.2% of campaign goal.
4. 
New primary staff salaries = $123,000. Based on
success of campaign and total response for music requests. 20.5% of campaign
goal.
                                                                FAQ
  Music Has Healing Power is a verified California, USA non-profit corporation
  IRS  EIN number 81-1539684
                                               
Cinema Show Music Can Be Heard On:  (Many more available) 




   


The Story
The healing power of music has been
referenced for centuries. Throughout history the idea of music as a healing
modality was well founded in Chinese, Egyptian and Greek history, suggesting
music is comforting, soothing and restorative for the soul.
Contemporary research shows that
music therapy benefits patients with stress, psychological and physical
problems. This brings about a sense of well being which helps manage illnesses
of all kinds.  Renowned Dr. Oliver Sachs,
neurologist, claims “music is the pathway in all patients”.  
http://www.oliversacks.com/books-by-oliver-sacks/musicophilia/  
A recent study in the Journal of Advanced Nursing, published in the UK, concluded that people
with depression who listened to music at least one hour each day reported a
reduction of symptoms of up to 25%. Another study by researchers at the
Cleveland Clinic in the US found that music helps ease unrelenting,
non-malignant pain in patients. Music has also been found effective in managing
pain caused by cancerous conditions in the body and procedural pain such as
chemotherapy.
Dr. Diana Vetter, a lead surgery researcher at the University
of Zurich in Switzerland, said “Informing
our patients before scheduled surgeries of the positive effect of music on
their wellbeing could be a low cost intervention that may enhance wellbeing and
possibly faster recovery”.
To assess
the impact of music on surgical outcomes, Vetter and colleagues analyzed data
from 47 studies, including 26 that looked at the effect of music before
procedures, 25 looking at music in the operating room, and 25 looking at music
during recovery. Overall, music was linked to about 31 percent less pain, 29
percent lower odds of using pain medication, and 34 percent less anxiety. In addition,
music was tied to 40 percent lower blood pressure and 27 percent lower heart
rate. 
"There now seems to be enough
evidence to support the formal adaptation of music interventions in clinical
guidelines." said
Marianne van der Heijden, a researcher at Erasmus Medical Center - Sophia
Children's Hospital in Rotterdam, The Netherlands.
Music
interventions shouldn't be difficult to provide at all and could be realized by
creating awareness among hospital staff, patients and their family members
about the positive effects of music," van der Heijden added. http://news.yahoo.com/music-not-just-good-soul-good-body-180422525.html
Watch Video Link Henry’s Story - Visualize the healing power of music – Truly
Amazing
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5FWn4JB2YLU



The Story Continued
Music Therapy is an established health
profession in which music is used to address physical, emotional, cognitive,
and social needs of individuals. Music therapy also provides avenues for
communication that can be helpful to those who find it difficult to express
themselves in words. Research in music therapy supports its effectiveness in
many areas such as: overall physical rehabilitation and facilitating movement,
increasing people's motivation to become engaged in their treatment, providing
emotional support for clients and their families, and providing an outlet for
expression of feelings. 
Examples of therapeutic
music which are noteworthy, from American Music
Therapy Association, (AMTA)
- A person with Alzheimer’s listening to an MP3 player with headphones of his/her
favorite songs.
- A piano player in the lobby of a hospital
- Nurses playing background music for patients

- Arts
educators
- A
high school student playing guitar in a nursing home
- A
choir singing on the pediatric floor of a hospital

Top 12 brain-based reasons
why music works in therapy, by
Karen Merzenich, writer-editor Brain HQ from Science Post, May 10, 2013
1. 
Music is
a core function in our brain. Our
brain is primed early on to respond to and process music. Research has shown
that day-old infants are able to detect differences in rhythmic patterns.Mothers across cultures and throughout time have used
lullabies and rhythmic rocking to calm crying babies. From an evolutionary
standpoint, music precedes language. We don’t yet know why, but our brains are
wired to respond to music. 
2. 
Our bodies entrain to rhythm. Have
you ever walked down the street, humming a song in your head, and noticed that
your walking to the beat? That’s called entrainment. Our motor systems
naturally entrain, or match, to a rhythmic beat. When a musical input
enters our central nervous system via the auditory nerve, most of the input
goes to the brain for processing. But some of it heads straight to motor nerves
in our spinal cord. This allows our muscles to move to the rhythm without our
having to think about it or “try.” It’s how we dance to music, tap our foot to
a rhythm, and walk in time to a beat. This is also why music therapists can
help a person who’s had a stroke re-learn how to walk and develop strength and
endurance in their upper bodies.
3. 
We have physiologic responses to music. Every
time your breathing quickens, your heart-rate increases, or you feel a shiver
down your spine, that’s your body responding physiologically to music.
Qualified music therapists can use this to help stimulate a person in a coma or
use music to effectively help someone relax.
4. 
Children (even infants) respond readily to music.
Any parent knows that it’s natural for a child to begin dancing and singing at
an early age. My kids both started rocking to music before they turned one. And
have you seen the YouTube video of the baby dancing to Beyonce? Children learn through music, art, and play, so
it’s important (even necessary) to use those mediums when working with children
in therapy.
5. 
Music taps into our emotions. Have
you ever listened to a piece of music and smiled? Or felt sad? Whether from the
music itself, or from our associations with the music, music taps into our
emotional systems. Many people use this in a “therapeutic” way, listening to
certain music that makes them feel a certain way. The ability for music to
easily access our emotions is very beneficial for music therapists.
6. 
Music helps improve our attention skills.
I was once working with a 4-year-old in the hospital. Her 10-month-old twin
sisters were visiting, playing with Grandma on the bed. As soon as I started
singing to the older sister, the twins stopped playing and stared at me, for a
full 3 minutes. Even from an early age, music can grab and hold our attention.
This allows music therapists to target attention and impulse control goals,
both basic skills we need to function and succeed.
7. 
Music uses shared neural circuits as speech.
This is almost a no-brainer (no pun intended), but listening to or singing
music with lyrics uses shared neural circuits as listening to and expressing
speech. Music therapists can use this ability to help a child learn to
communicate or help someone who’s had a stroke re-learn how to talk again.
8. 
Music
enhances learning. Do you remember how you learned
your ABCs? Through a song! The inherent structure and emotional pull of music
makes it an easy tool for teaching concepts, ideas, and information. Music
is an effective mnemonic device and can “tag” information, not only making it
easy to learn, but also easy to later recall.
9. 
Music
taps into our memories. Have
you ever been driving, heard a song on the radio, then immediately been taken
to a certain place, a specific time in your life, or a particular person? Music
is second only to smell for its ability to stimulate our memory in a very
powerful way. Music therapists who work with older adults with dementia have
countless stories of how music stimulates their clients to reminisce about
their life.
10. 
Music is
a social experience. Our
ancestors bonded and passed on their stories and knowledge through song,
stories, and dance. Even today, many of our music experiences are shared with a
group, whether playing in band or an elementary music class, listening to jazz
at a restaurant, or singing in church choir. Music makes it easy for music
therapists to structure and facilitate a group process.
11. 
Music is
predictable, structured, and organized–and our brain likes it! Music often has a predictable steady beat,
organized phrases, and a structured form. If you think of most
country/folk/pop/rock songs you know, they’re often organized with a
verse-chorus structure. They’re organized in a way that we like and enjoy
listening to over and over again. Even sound waves that make up a single tone
or an entire chord are organized in mathematical ratios–and our brains really
like this predictability and structure.
12. 
Music is
non-invasive, safe and motivating.
We can’t forget that most people really enjoy music. This is not the most
important reason why music works in therapy, but it’s the icing on the cake.
The Evidence On Music Therapy Continued,
from Evidence – Based Living, Cornell University 
We’ve all
heard the idiom, “Music is good for the soul.” But, according to the evidence,
it’s good for your health as well.
A new study published in the Journal of the American Medical
Association found that children admitted to
the emergency department who listened to music during routine procedures showed
less distress and reported lower pain scores than those who didn’t listen to
music.
The study
included a total of 42 children aged 3 to 11 years who had an IV line placed.
Half of them were randomly selected to listen to music selected by a music
therapist during the procedure. Health care providers reported that it was
easier to insert the IV line in children who were listening to the music and health
providers also reported more satisfaction with the placement compared to those
who did not listen to music.
Those are
some convincing results, but still only a single study. So we went looking for
systematic reviews on the impact of music in medical settings. It turns out,
there is plenty more evidence showing the positive effects of music on
health.  Among them:


A 2011 review published in the Cochrane libraries found music therapy and music medicine
     interventions can help cancer patients. The review found some positive
     effects of music on anxiety, pain, mood, quality of life, heart rate, respiratory
     rate, and blood pressure.
Another Cochrane review published in 2009 looked for studies measuring whether music
     therapy is useful in treating depression. The reviewers only found five
     studies appropriate for the review. Four of them concluded that patients
     exposed to music therapy had a greater reduction in symptoms compared to
     those who didn’t listen to music.
And a third review published in the Journal of
     Advanced Nursing in
     2002 looked at the impact of music therapy on patients admitted to the
     hospital. Researchers reviewed 19 studies, and found music therapy
     improved patients anxiety levels in the hospital. Researchers recommended
     music therapy as an effective way to calm patients.


The
bottom line: There is plenty of evidence to show that music therapy used in
health care settings  can help calm
patients. And given there are no side effects associated to music listening,
it’s certainly a treatment worth trying.


Benefits
Of Music In Schools
Nearly everyone enjoys music, whether by listening to it,
singing, or playing an instrument. But despite this almost universal interest,
many schools are having to do away with their music education programs. This is
a mistake, with schools losing not only an enjoyable subject, but a subject
that can enrich students’ lives and education. Read on to learn why music
education is so important, and how it offers benefits even beyond itself.
1. Musical training helps develop language and reasoning:
Students who have early musical training will develop the areas of the brain
related to language and reasoning. The left side of the brain is better
developed with music, and songs can help imprint information on young minds.
2. A mastery of memorization: Even when performing
with sheet music, student musicians are constantly using their memory to
perform. The skill of memorization can serve students well in education and
beyond.
3. Students learn to improve their work: Learning
music promotes craftsmanship, and students learn to want to create good work
instead of mediocre work. This desire can be applied to all subjects of study.
4. Increased coordination: Students who practice
with musical instruments can improve their hand-eye coordination. Just like
playing sports, children can develop motor skills when playing music.
5. A sense of achievement: Learning to play pieces
of music on a new instrument can be a challenging, but achievable goal.
Students who master even the smallest goal in music will be able to feel proud
of their achievement.
6. Kids stay engaged in school: An enjoyable
subject like music can keep kids interested and engaged in school. Student
musicians are likely to stay in school to achieve in other subjects.
7. Success in society: Music is the fabric of our
society, and music can shape abilities and character. Students in band or
orchestra are less likely to abuse substances over their lifetime. Musical
education can greatly contribute to children’s intellectual development as
well.
8. Emotional development: Students of music can be
more emotionally developed, with empathy towards other cultures They also tend
to have higher self esteem and are better at coping with anxiety.
9. Students learn pattern recognition: Children can
develop their math and pattern-recognition skills with the help of musical
education. Playing music offers repetition in a fun format.
10. Better SAT scores: Students who have experience
with music performance or appreciation score higher on the SAT. One report
indicates 63 points higher on verbal and 44 points higher on math for students
in music appreciation courses.
11. Fine-tuned auditory skills: Musicians can
better detect meaningful, information-bearing elements in sounds, like the
emotional meaning in a baby’s cry. Students who practice music can have better
auditory attention, and pick out predictable patterns from surrounding noise.
12. Music builds imagination and intellectual
curiosity: Introducing music in the early childhood years can help foster a
positive attitude toward learning and curiosity. Artistic education develops
the whole brain and develops a child’s imagination.
13. Music can be relaxing: Students can fight
stress by learning to play music. Soothing music is especially helpful in
helping kids relax.
14. Musical instruments can teach discipline: Kids
who learn to play an instrument can learn a valuable lesson in discipline. They
will have to set time aside to practice and rise to the challenge of learning
with discipline to master playing their instrument.
15. Preparation for the creative economy: Investing
in creative education can prepare students for the 21st century workforce. The
new economy has created more artistic careers, and these jobs may grow faster
than others in the future.
16. Development in creative thinking: Kids who
study the arts can learn to think creatively. This kind of education can help
them solve problems by thinking outside the box and realizing that there may be
more than one right answer.
17. Music can develop spatial intelligence:
Students who study music can improve the development of spatial intelligence,
which allows them to perceive the world accurately and form mental pictures.
Spatial intelligence is helpful for advanced mathematics and more.
18. Kids can learn teamwork: Many musical education
programs require teamwork as part of a band or orchestra. In these groups,
students will learn how to work together and build camaraderie.
19. Responsible risk-taking: Performing a musical
piece can bring fear and anxiety. Doing so teaches kids how to take risks and
deal with fear, which will help them become successful and reach their
potential.
20. Better self-confidence:
With encouragement from teachers and parents, students playing a musical
instrument can build pride and confidence. Musical education is also likely to
develop better communication for students.







~ ~ ~




Notable Music Quotes:
Mitchell Gaynor, M.D., Sounds of Healing
"You can look at disease as a form of disharmony. And there's no organ system in the body that's not affected by sound and music and vibration. "
 Oliver
Sachs, M.D.
"I regard music therapy as a tool of
great power in many neurological disorders -- Parkinson's and Alzheimer's --
because of its unique capacity to organize or reorganize cerebral function when
it has been damaged." 
Dr. Ira Altschuler (of the Eloise State Hospital) (1942)
"Eventually , musical therapists will compose prescriptions after the manner of a pharmacist...."
Corinne Heline (1882-1975)
"The magic of "Musical Medicine" will come into its own. The application of such healing potencies will not be limited just to man's body and mind. It will be an agency for building and healing his soul as well. "

"Emotions of any kind can be evoked by melody and rhythm; therefore music has the power to form character. "
Robert Assagioli M.D.(1888-1974) Founder of Transpersonal Psychology
"We trust that the magic of sound, will contribute an ever greater measure to the relief of human suffering." 
Beethoven (1770-1827)
"Music is the mediator between the life of the senses and the life of the spirit."

story:
Thanks to everyone for their contributions - the campaign is now closed and there are enough funds to proceed with the recordings. Of course, more support is still needed to complete the design/ pressing/ promotion process. If you'd like to claim one of the rewards and/or support please send a message via the Basically Baker Volume II Facebook Group - thank you!

Be a part of a very special celebration of the life and music of jazz composer, author, and educator David Baker. Claim your recording now or join at any other reward level and support the recording, production, and major national release of “Basically Baker Volume 2: The Big Band Music of David Baker” by the Buselli-Wallarab Jazz Orchestra. Your contributions are tax deductible as funds will go to the Patois non-profit organization.

Upon release, 100% of all proceeds generated by sales of the recording will go directly to the David N. Baker Scholarship Fund.

This project seeks to fulfill two very important goals:

·  To expose more people globally to the ingenious jazz composition of David Baker and

·  to provide support for talented young students to study at the Jacobs School of Music Jazz Studies Program. These goals were very important to David and remain so to his family and wife, Lida.

Yes, $50,000 is a big number. Patois Records, a successful label from the Bay Area that has been responsible for producing a number of Grammy nominated recordings in recent years, has pledged full support for the album release and provide its resources for the September launch.

Some of the expenses include:

·  Hiring 20+ world class musicians

·  Music restoration, engraving, and copying

·  Recording, editing, mixing, and mastering

·  Artwork and album design

·  Licensing and copyright fees

·  CD production

·  Radio and print promotion

·  Legal fees

An added feature of this project is the rerelease of Basically Baker, Vol I. Recorded in 2005, this CD made Downbeat Magazine’s “100 best Recordings of the Decade” list in 2010. Virtually impossible to find in recent years, this amazing recording will once again be available!

We’ll give you regular updates including band personnel, tune selection, and some background into the process along the way. Check back frequently to see how everything is progressing. For all of you who knew and loved and benefited from the wisdom of David Baker, here is your chance to give back in a way that would make David very happy. Thanks for your support of this great project.

production
·  Radio
and print promotion
·  Legal
fees
An added feature of this project is the rerelease of
Basically Baker, Vol I. Recorded in 2005, this CD made Downbeat Magazine’s “100
best Recordings of the Decade” list in 2010. Virtually impossible to find in
recent years, this amazing recording will once again be available!
We’ll give you regular updates including band personnel,
tune selection, and some background into the process along the way. Check back
frequently to see how everything is progressing. For all of you who knew and loved and benefited from the wisdom of David Baker, here is your chance to
 give back in a way that would make David very happy. Thanks for your support of
this great project.

story:
Music and Passion

I am Jessi Campo and I am  a singer, entertainer and songwriter who is passionate about my music and my culture so I have created my 4th CD as a tribute of La Lupe , a famous Cuban singer and her passion. I want to share her music and my passion plus some of my own personal touches with the world.
The reason I feel so passionate about this project is because my dad was a famous Cuban performer who back in the days of the golden era of music performed in Cuba with a Celia Cruz then at the Tropicana with great legends like Josephine Baker  and Bebo Valdez.  Later on in his career he came to USA and in New York performed at the Palladium with his sidekick my mom and other iconic legends such as Tito Puente and Tony Bennett, The Supremes and many more.
So you must understand my desire to want  to share my  Cuban heritage and music plus carry on my dad's legacy as performer. This music is timeless and all generations can appreciate it once they experience it. In order to have this amazing CD  reach everybody  worldwide there has to be promotions, marketing and manufacturing , so funding is necessary to make that happen.
I have put in most of my own money and had amazing friends which have contributed their talents such as Tito Puente Jr who Co produced 2 songs on CD. I am almost finished with the CD , but it is still incomplete .  In order to fulfill my dream plus be eligible for bigger and better things we need additional funds to do it right!


What We Need & What You Get

There will be fabulous perks for your  funding and you can also make give us suggestions that would be fun and of interest to you.
Photo shoot-$1000
Video shoot- $1000
Image stylist hair and makeup- $400
Mastering -$1000
Manufacture- $800
Publicist -$800
Promoter-$1200

You can make a difference

By being a part of a movement to bring back classics and songs that transport you back in time that become part of you your emotions and memories. Reconnecting the world with timeless music.

There may be some challenges along the way but I will overcome them because  my Daddy has a always said to me to never give up.

I have 3 prior CDs to show for it and 3 music videos and most recently 6 songs in a feature film  soundtrack called "El Sueno" about the Dream Act. Plus my 2014 CD "Con Corazon" was considered for a Latin Grammy Nomination in 3 categories.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you have friends in the music industry or related businesses that can assist my process and be a part of my journey I would be eternally grateful so I can get this project to the next level. 
Also every little bit helps just telling your friends so new fans go buy my previous Jazz and Bolero CD "At Last" a tribute to my Daddy who was in show business for 40 years with famous people from Cuba during the golden era of music and performed in movies and stages at the Tropicana.

I am grateful for your consideration to assist me in showing all the young artists in the world , every dream is possible with hard work and other people that believe in you and your music . I breathe and live my music and I hope my voice and songs will be a part of those moments that take your breathe away !
Gratefully
Jessi Campo

story:
The K.DAVER Story

If music is as big apart of your life as it is mine then you know that there is no substitute for a live show. The energy, atmosphere, and excitement cannot be matched. I’ve been offered the opportunity of a LIFETIME to tour this fall(35+dates) with some very established groups! I’ve been fully independent my entire career and there isn’t a part of this job I love more than performing for my fans. Being fully independent is amazing in the freedom it gives me to be flexible creatively. However the freedom does come with a huge financial burden, especially since most people don’t pay for the actual music anymore. 

What Do I Need?

I would love to raise between $10,000 - $15,000 but let me break it down for you.

I have a team of professionals who will be working on this tour I need to pay including 1 merch salesperson, 1 hypeman, 1 tour manager, 1 roadie/sound tech. I have already paid for vehicle, banners, microphones, promotional material and merchandise.(Almost $9,000)

Our travel costs, hotels, and food alone are over $8,000. 

Thats right it’s not easy touring with the big dogs. This is the necessary next step in my career and this is where I NEED your help!

WHAT DO YOU GET?

I believe i’ve created some awesome ways for your to participate in the push for this tour. From signed cds, to VIP/Dinner for four. Also very exciting Sponsorship options for companies! This will be a national tour across the United States so your product will have plenty of eyes on it with whatever package you decide!

Please help spread the word with all your friends and family and remember to ‘share via the Indiegogo share buttons. I can’t wait to meet all my supporters when i’m in your city because after all you are and will always be my drive and reason for doing this! Thank you all again and lets take this to the next level!

K.DAVER

story:
http://www.anotherrockopera.com

Armageddon came without warning. It was over equally as fast. A few lost souls were saved and they created Purgatory. In their subterranean world only the most faithful make up The Order. The Order’s rules are strict, their punishments harsh. The most heinous crime is to go against the will of The Order; the punishment, banishment to the hell above. Nikola and Renata love each other and love their daughter Agatha even more.  But while Renata has always taught her daughter to believe fully in the faith and respect The Order above all else, Nikola wanted her to be strong willed, to think for herself.

When Agatha refuses to join The Order at her coming-of-age, The Leader, Cyril has no choice but to banish her to Hell. Will she have the courage to stand her ground when she knows society is wrong? Will her teenage rebellion be the end of Purgatory?

story:
Hello! I’m Michael Levy, a lifelong folk, gospel and jazz musician and songwriter, and advocate for the sustainable well-being and beauty of our planet. “Great Big Love” is a collection of songs I've written over the past few years as a passionate approach to engaging and empowering people on climate change, one of the most crucial challenges in the history of our species. Just because we are in a time of global crisis doesn’t mean we should stop singing. Quite the contrary! (Here's a link to some songs I've recorded already.)

I have begun recording these songs because I feel they have to potential to help empower people far and wide, in places I may never get to myself. Although I have spent a few thousand dollars of my own money, I need help to create a complete CD and downloadable album of professionally-made recordings. Money that you contribute will all be spent on the recording process, which costs upwards of $1,000 per song. Your contribution of any size will be a huge help in getting the music to the people!

What we need

My immediate goal is to raise $5,000, which is the minimum required to finish the CD. However, the STRETCH goal is $10,000, which will provide more hours of valuable studio time, additional top-notch musicians, and an overall better result. My SUPER YOGA GUMBY STRETCH goal of $15,000 means the best of everything, including bringing in a professional producer to add polish to the creation, which could allow this music to achieve even wider distribution.

What you get (perks! perks!)

OK, now the fun part: what you get at different donation levels. There are a whole range of perks, from a hug and hi-five at the $5 level to a private house concert (and more) at the $500 level. Check out all of them on the right side of the page. (Note: to make sure you get the perk, click on the perk itself, not the Contribute Now button.)

And guess what? Even if I don't reach my basic funding goal :-( you're still guaranteed to get all your perks!

Why is this important?

Ever since I woke up to the reality of climate change about 10 years ago, I have found that feelings of isolation, fear and powerlessness are the biggest pitfalls that stop people from taking action – and lead to burnout for activists. That's why I started writing these songs. At my concerts, I have found that people feel the togetherness they need in order to dare to care, to consider what they might like to do, or to keep going with their work. They no longer feel like they have to hold the crisis at bay, in a painful corner of their minds.

By contributing to this campaign, you will be part of giving people hope that we can tackle this seemingly overwhelming challenge together. I will keep you posted via email and Facebook about every development. I’ll also be delighted to get your feedback on the project as it moves forward.

Other Ways You Can Help

It may be that you just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help. Here are some things you can do:

  • Get the word out and make some noise about this campaign. Indiegogo has share tools if you are a social media person, and there is always regular email and heck, even regular talking (still the best communication!). Talk it up!
  • Contribute your skills if you are a musician or some other kind of performer, an event promoter, a graphic designer, an artist...
  • Let me know if you have leads on performance opportunities (in the Monterey and San Francisco Bay Areas).

Thank you for joining me in celebration, beauty, resistance, creativity, hope, and love for our people and planet.

story:
A Mystery Has Begun…

In late April, VK received a phone call…

A few days later, a chilling note arrived….


The band has been abducted, and it couldn't come at a worse time- The record is written and ready to be recorded! But without the Accomplice…how will The Spider spin????

It's time to mobilize, #ArachnidArmy

To raise the ransom money, VK is offering rewards to all contributors. We don't know how diabolical our kidnapper is at this stage, so each dollar could be saving a finger, or providing a chicken wing. As you can see, their accommodations look sinister! :(



Time is ticking.

  • The quicker we can rescue the boys, the quicker we can get back to making music! We have rewards to accommodate every level of assistance that you can offer, so peruse and choose!
  • Every week new perks will be added until we get our boys home!
A few words from VK:
https://www.facebook.com/vklynne/videos/1015506...

Every click counts!

We need to get the story out to as many eyeballs as possible, if we're going to succeed in our mission!

  • Share the campaign on your social networks! 
  • Post photos of TSA memorabilia and show Arno & Justin our solidarity with them!
  • Our hashtags are #SpiderAbduction #FreeJaylee 

LET'S GET OUR BAND BACK!!!!!

story:
We're still not fully funded. Even though the campaign is "officially" over, you can still donate. Just follow this LINK

It's Time!!

It's finally time for Baltimore's first ever, all day, free to the public Jazz Fest.

We're going to present 50 or so of Baltimore's best jazz musicians in beautiful Druid Hill Park on October 1, 2016.  Starting time is 12:00 noon and the sound of jazz will continue on into the evening.

You'll hear the next generation when we open with the Dunbar HS jazz band,  They'll be followed with some straight ahead be-bop - the Greg Hatza ORGANization and the Clarence Ward III All Stars. We will also have Rumba Club doing Latin Jazz like nobody else, Art Sherrod Jr playing the smooth sounds of contemporary jazz, Baltimore's hottest new jazz group, the Hot Club of Baltimore playing Gypsy Jazz, and wrapping everything up will be the Baltimore Legends (think alumni of Sportsman's Lounge and Pennsylvania Avenue).

TO MAKE ALL THIS HAPPEN, WE NEED YOUR HELP.  First of all, we have to pay our musicians. And then there's permits, sound, lights, stage, drum set, fencing, tents, chairs, tables, programs, posters, security, toilets, etc etc etc. You get the picture?

The Baltimore Jazz Alliance is a small not-for-profit (too literally!) 501(c)(3) organization that's been promoting jazz in Baltimore since 2004. We're still trying to line up grant money and some corporate sponsors, but we have a ways to go to get this paid for.

WE CAN MAKE THIS HAPPEN WITH YOUR HELP!

Thank you on behalf of the Baltimore Jazz Community for your tax deductible contribution.

Find out more at http://baltimorejazzfest.com/

story:
MY STORY

I’m Brandon Stansell. I grew up about hour away from, well…everything, and spent my life wanting to move to Nashville and become a singer. So at 18 years-old, I did! I spent 5 years living-in and loving the city before I left for New York and then eventually landing in LA. 

LA living has inspired this "California Country" sound that I have been working towards for the past year or so, and that energy is coming through in the songs we're writing now.  Inherent in all of the new material is a theme of optimism, and taking a chance on something that could just be worth the risk.   

THE DETAILS

The full scope of this project includes producing the three-song EP and two full-length music videos for two of the three songs. Nashville-based producer, writer, and guitarist Erik Halbig has signed on to produce the record. I met Erik a few years ago through my good friend and supporter Ty Herndon.

Joining the team again, and building off our incredible collaboration on the video for DEAR JOHN, will be director Trent Atkinson.  

 
Trent's vision for the videos is to build on the cinematic scope of our first work, and to lean into the energy of the new music with visuals that compliment and take the work to an even broader audience. 
 

To pay a little something to all of the wonderful people who have signed up for this adventure, the fundraising goal is $10,000, split between recording the tracks, and producing the videos. This will be a professional product, made on a shoestring - so if we can exceed our initial goal, the scope of what we're able to achieve will also expand.

I have included a few perks for contributions to the campaign including digital download cards for the new EP, signed copies of the DEAR JOHN EP and more!  

A SINCERE THANK YOU

I truly appreciate everyone taking the time to support the SLOW DOWN EP project! I have been writing and working toward this moment for the past year and, with your help, I am thrilled at the opportunity to bring this music to LIFE! 

I also know that not everyone can contribute, and I absolutely get it (trust me, I lived in New York City for three years with barely two wooden-nickels to rub together on any given day), but that doesn't mean you can’t help! Share this project and help spread the word to your friends and loved ones!

xo

Brandon

story:
Short Summary

 I'm Joshua Lee, the Founder of this project. I am a musician/singer/songwriter; mostly in the rock and acoustic-driven genre. I am trying to provide an option for the kind of people who provided me care when I had NOTHING. The homeless pandemic in this country is ridiculous, especially when those who have the least are usually more generous than anyone else. There is nothing more heart wrenching to me than to see someone who has nothing be treated worse than a stray dog. So, with the connections I have I'm going to put out this new album with appearances by some well known (and some lesser known) musicians. I can't divulge the possibilities yet, but they are endless depending on the amount of support we get for this cause. With your help, we can make sure that a lot of men, women and children have a great Christmas IN DOORS, with dignity, warmth, and love...and hopefully a steady income and a home of their own. I promise you will NOT be disappointed in the songs, lineup, or the wonderful production by Mr. Ben Trexel.

What We Need & What You Get

We are founding a Chapter 617 Corporation Not-For-Profit, this costs around $100; After this we have to file form IRS 10-23 for our 501(c)(3) tax deductible designation, which costs $400 more; After that we will be eligible for several federal and corporate grants and your obligation is over for the cause unless you choose to remain active. In the meantime, and with the rest of what we're trying to raise, I'm personally putting together a team of amazing musicians, some of whom you are VERY familiar with, and the very best production team in the southeast. You're going to get a great deal on some epic music and knowing that YOU made the difference.

Risks & Challenges

What we're facing is promotion. We need everyone to become involved in the outcome of these initial steps or the whole project will fall through. The purpose is to fund the new charity, which will be called THE HELPING H.A.N.D. NETWORK, INC. (Homeless Americans Needless Despair) If you have any other questions that aren't answered here feel free to call me personally: (850) 358-9442, or send me a message on facebook.

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign. Post links or tell your friends and family. Whatever you have the time and desire to do!
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!

And THANK YOU SO MUCH; From Myself, Malinda, Ben Trexel, and the MANY MANY people that are going to be impacted by this project!
story_txt:
Short Summary
 I'm Joshua Lee, the Founder of this project. I am a musician/singer/songwriter; mostly in the rock and acoustic-driven genre. I am trying to provide an option for the kind of people who provided me care when I had NOTHING. The homeless pandemic in this country is ridiculous, especially when those who have the least are usually more generous than anyone else. There is nothing more heart wrenching to me than to see someone who has nothing be treated worse than a stray dog. So, with the connections I have I'm going to put out this new album with appearances by some well known (and some lesser known) musicians. I can't divulge the possibilities yet, but they are endless depending on the amount of support we get for this cause. With your help, we can make sure that a lot of men, women and children have a great Christmas IN DOORS, with dignity, warmth, and love...and hopefully a steady income and a home of their own. I promise you will NOT be disappointed in the songs, lineup, or the wonderful production by Mr. Ben Trexel.

What We Need & What You Get
We are founding a Chapter 617 Corporation Not-For-Profit, this costs around $100; After this we have to file form IRS 10-23 for our 501(c)(3) tax deductible designation, which costs $400 more; After that we will be eligible for several federal and corporate grants and your obligation is over for the cause unless you choose to remain active. In the meantime, and with the rest of what we're trying to raise, I'm personally putting together a team of amazing musicians, some of whom you are VERY familiar with, and the very best production team in the southeast. You're going to get a great deal on some epic music and knowing that YOU made the difference.


Risks & Challenges
What we're facing is promotion. We need everyone to become involved in the outcome of these initial steps or the whole project will fall through. The purpose is to fund the new charity, which will be called THE HELPING H.A.N.D. NETWORK, INC. (Homeless Americans Needless Despair) If you have any other questions that aren't answered here feel free to call me personally: (850) 358-9442, or send me a message on facebook.

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign. Post links or tell your friends and family. Whatever you have the time and desire to do!
Use the Indiegogo share tools!

And THANK YOU SO MUCH; From Myself, Malinda, Ben Trexel, and the MANY MANY people that are going to be impacted by this project!

story:
Short Summary

Raising funds to bring Hafler Trio (Andrew McKenzie) to Austin for a 4-day workshop culminating in a 5th day performance by workshop participants, with some sections of time open to the public for experience and participation if they choose.  We specifically need money to cover Mr. McKenzie's transportation from Estonia to Austin, as well as room and board during his stay.

" ''''''' " (Seven Quotation Marks) by Hafler Trio. March 1st - March 5th, 2017.   Open to absolutely anyone interested with or without any artistic or musical experience. Workshop covers a variety of performance, conceptual, psychological and personally meaningful topics, culminating in a 5th day of 12-14 hour performance opportunity available to workshop participants.  Performance will be recorded and an edited version will be provided by Andrew exclusively to the workshop particpants only - these recordings will not be available to the public or anyone else in any other medium.

  • We are a group of experimental and avant-garde art & music fans, creators and performers who have been enthusiastic fans of Hafler Trio for many decades
  • We have received Andrew's permission to organize his workshop and a group performance of his piece " ''''''' " (Seven Quotation Marks) for March 1st through March 5th, 2017, and we need your help to raise the funds to produce the event.
  • BUT....  WE NEED THE FUNDS SOONER THAN LATER, because if we wait until January or February, we will miss various deadlines and would likely not be able to produce the event.
  • This will be the first time that Hafler Trio has performed in the United States in many years, and the first time Andrew has been back to Texas in more than 25 years!  As such this workshop and performance not only presents a rare opportunity to experience the Hafler Trio, but a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to learn from and collaborate with Andrew McKenzie himself!  The workshop and performance are open to absolutely anyone; there is no musical or artistic experience required whatsoever.

What We Need & What You Get

  • We need funding to cover Andrew McKenzie's transportation costs, food and lodging; fees for our workshop and performance spaces; costs of the audio and other equipment required to produce the show; artist fees; show programs and other printed materials & marketing costs
  • If you sign up as a participant, you will get FIVE DAYS with Andrew McKenzie!  Depending on which level you sign up at, you will also receive a recording of the performance edited by Mr. McKenzie after the event, that is ONLY AVAILBLE TO WORKSHOP PARTICIPANTS.  There will also be a level where you receive the " ''''''' " (Seven Quotation Marks) book, which contains relevant background and detail about the piece. (UPDATE: The book WILL NOT be amended with information from the Austin performance as previously reported.  You will receive the book as currently available.  Apologies for any confusion regarding this.)
  • If we do not reach our entire goal in time, we will seek to reschedule the event at a later date if Andrew is amendable to this, or we will use it to bring another experimental music performer in the future.

The Impact

  • This piece " ''''''' " (Seven Quotation Marks) has never been performed in the US, has only been performed anywhere a handful of times, and in general Mr. McKenzie has withdrawn from the regular release of music through the physical and digital means common these days.  Additionally, this piece is designed to stretch the personal capacities of all involved in ways that truly provide a transformative experience that will continue to unfold in their lives long after the performance is over.
  • In our world of throw-away products and experiences, " ''''''' " (Seven Quotation Marks) is the exact opposite, and as a result *cannot not* have an impact on the performers and audience that goes far beyond anything they can experience anywhere else in their lives.

Risks & Challenges

  • Put simply, if we are
    • 1.) not able to secure approximately 10 to 15 people who can commit to the full workshop, and
    • 2.) not able to raise at least $2000 by December 31st, 2016, we risk the entire project being postponed indefintely or cancelled.  
  • Having secured Mr. McKenzie's agreement to come to Austin, this would be a major disappointment and there is a likelihood that Mr. McKenzie would not agree to return at a later date.  We have his agreement now, so it would be a shame to let it slip through our fingers!
  • We are also seeking funding from various grant organizations, however most of them require some existing funds that they will match or multiply.  For example, one grant program will match what we raise if they see there is enough interest and benefit to the community, so if we are able to raise $2000, they will provide $2000 as well.  If we can engage a few of these programs and leverage the funds we raise here, we might be able to match our goal very quickly.  However this entirely depends on raising the initial funds here.
  • One of the ways that grant organizations measure interest and benefit is by the number of workshop participants and advanced ticket sales, so if you are interested, PLEASE SIGN UP for the workshop ASAP, or if you can't make the workshop, PURCHASE YOUR TICKET instead.  The sooner you do this, the better we will be able to make our case to the granting organizations, and the more secure this whole project becomes!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, that doesn't mean you can't help!

  • PLEASE get the word out and make some noise about this workshop and performance!
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the word on Facebook, Twitter, and everywhere else you can!
  • Additionally, if you can't make the workshop or performance, but just love experimental music, art, and weird things in general, consider offering as much money as you would like as a general donation.  Your name will be included in the sponsors section of the printed program.
  • Let us know you're coming by clicking "GOING" on the Facebook Event page! https://www.facebook.com/events/129718027517048

Other Ways You Can Help

PLEASE get the word out and make some noise about this workshop and performance!
